questions.question: Question 1: Which is a mood stabiliser with an anti-suicidal role?
questions.explanation:
Lithium is a mood stabilizer with an antisuicidal role. Maintenance treatment with lithium has shown to decrease the rate of suicide in mood disorders. 
Lithium was found to be better than other mood stabilizers such as carbamazepine, lamotrigine, 
and valproate. Lithium is also used in recurrent depression with a cyclic pattern is controlled by either lithium or 
imipramine. It is also used to augment standard antidepressant response in acute major 
depression in those patients who have had an inadequate response to monotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 25-year-old man is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his mother with complaints that he 
has been behaving aggressively for the last 10 days. He believes he owns the biggest 
automobile company in the world and talks about how his made-up company will put 
satellites into space someday. She also says that he sleeps for only 3 hours a day. Which of the 
following drugs cannot be used to treat this patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features given are suggestive of acute mania in this patient and lamotrigine is not 
indicated in this condition. It requires a slow, extended titration to minimize the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome and is 
used for maintenance therapy in bipolar disorder. Lithium, sodium valproate, carbamazepine, and atypical antipsychotics are indicated in acute 
mania. Lithium is indicated in both acute mania and maintenance therapy.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient is being treated with lithium for manic-depressive psychosis. Which of the following 
is true about the use of this drug?

options.a: Can be given alone for acute episodes
options.b: Serum concentration monitoring is not used for dose adjustment
options.c: Cause benign and reversible flattening of T wave on ECG

questions.explanation:
Prolonged use of lithium causes a benign and reversible flattening of T-wave. Option A: Lithium is usually not given alone in acute episodes as the onset of antimanic action is 
slow. Benzodiazepines, anticonvulsants, or atypical antipsychotics are administered along with 
lithium in the early phases of treatment. Option B: Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index and monitoring of serum concentration is 
used for guiding dose adjustment. Option D: Lithium causes significant weight gain.

Sold by @itachibot A patient on lithium therapy is diagnosed to be hypertensive. Which of the following 
antihypertensive drugs is contraindicated here?
questions.explanation:
Thiazides are contraindicated in patients who are on lithium therapy. Thiazide diuretics cause significant reductions in Li+ clearance that result in toxic levels. 324 
Sold by @itachibot The K+ sparing diuretics have modest effects on lithium excretion, with a mild increase in serum 
levels. Loop diuretics have a limited impact on Li+ serum levels.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with a history of mania, on lithium therapy, is brought with complaints of vomiting 
and multiple episodes of diarrhea. On examination, coarse tremors and an ataxic gait are 
noted. What is the expected level of serum lithium in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features are suggestive of lithium toxicity, where serum levels >1.5 mEq/L are 
considered toxic. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (0.8–1.2 mEq/L) and therefore requires monitoring to 
suspect toxicity. The toxic effects of lithium usually start manifesting when the serum level crosses 
1.5 mEq/L. Acute intoxication is characterized by: • Vomiting • Profuse diarrhea • Coarse tremors • Ataxia • Coma • Convulsions. A fine action tremor is common in patients taking lithium at therapeutic doses and can develop at 
any time during treatment. Therapeutic lithium tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the 
arms, and nonprogressive.Tremor from lithium toxicity is coarser and more disabling, may also 
affect the legs, and occurs with other symptoms of toxicity. Serious effects of lithium toxicity will involve confusion, hyperreflexia, and seizures. Motor and 
cognitive side effects can become irreversible with persistent cerebellar tremor being the most 
common.

questions.question: Question 6: At what serum lithium levels would you consider dialysis in acute lithium toxicity?
questions.explanation:
In acute overdoses, hemodialysis is indicated in: • Serum lithium level is > 4.0 mEq/L • Patients exhibiting symptoms of toxicity. Note: While hemodialysis is considered when serum lithium level is 4.0 mEq/L and above, signs of 
lithium toxicity usually start showing when the serum level is > 1.5 mEq/L. One should not get 
confused between the two.

questions.question: Question 7: Patients with which of the following conditions do not warrant lithium therapy?
questions.explanation:
325 
Sold by @itachibot Lithium is not indicated in generalized anxiety disorder. Bipolar disorder is the primary indication for lithium. Option A: Effect of leukocytosis may hasten recovery from cancer chemotherapy-induced 
leukopenia and agranulocytosis. Option B: Unipolar depression can be treated with lithium as an adjuvant in resistant cases. Option C: Vasculogenic headaches like cluster headaches.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following must be administered initially in patients with acute mania with 
psychotic features?
questions.explanation:
In acute mania, even in patients without overt psychotic manifestations, atypical antipsychotics 
like olanzapine is used initially for rapid control of psychosis. Atypical antipsychotics are also 
effective as monotherapy. The therapeutic effects of lithium, carbamazepine, and valproic acid are seen only after a few 
days. Therefore they are effective only with daily dosing with adequate serum monitoring.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with mania has been initiated on lithium therapy. While counseling the patient 
about the medication, which of the following effects do you mention as the most common 
CNS adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
The most common CNS adverse effect of lithium in the therapeutic dose range is fine postural 
hand tremors. Therapeutic lithium tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the arms, and 
nonprogressive. Options A and B: Ataxia, slurred speech, and/or incoordination are adverse effects seen during 
peak CNS/serum concentrations. Single bedtime dosing can avoid these adverse effects. Option D: Coarse tremors are seen in case of lithium toxicity and is more disabling and may also 
affect the legs.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient on chronic lithium therapy is diagnosed to have hypothyroidism. What should be 
the next course of action?

options.a: Stop lithium immediately and start exogenous thyroid replacement
options.b: Stop lithium immediately and wait for normalisation of thyroid status
options.c: Continue lithium along with exogenous thyroid replacement
options.d: Decrease the dose of lithium and wait for normalisation of thyroid status

questions.explanation:
Hypothyroidism developed in a patient on chronic lithium therapy is treated by exogenous 
replacement of thyroid hormones. It is not a reason for the discontinuation of lithium therapy.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 34-year-old woman presents with complaints of increased frequency of urination and 
fatigue. She gives a history of lithium intake for bipolar mood disorder for the past 6 years. 
On investigations, her serum osmolality was 300 mOsm/L and her urine osmolality was 250 
mOsm/L. Which of the following drugs is used to treat this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of lithium intake and investigations showing serum 
osmolality and urine osmolality is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus secondary to 
lithium toxicity. Amiloride is the drug of choice for this condition. 326 
Sold by @itachibot Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It inhibits the renal epithelial Na+ channel (ENac 
channel) in collecting duct cells. It blocks the entry of Li+ ions through the ENac channels and 
thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium. Thiazide diuretics cause significant reductions in Li+ clearance that result in toxic 
levels. Thiazides are contraindicated in patients who are on lithium therapy.

questions.question:
Question 12: A female patient is on first-line pharmacological therapy for bipolar disorder for 6 months. 
She is fasting for a few days due to religious reasons and presented with seizures, coarse 
tremors, confusion, and weakness of limbs. Which of the following investigations should be 
done to help diagnose her condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features given in the question are most likely suggestive of lithium toxicity, and hence 
serum lithium levels should be measured to confirm it. Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of 
management in bipolar disorder. The kidney handles both lithium and Na+ in the same way via ENac channel. Thus during 
fasting/dehydration, along with Na+ reabsorption in renal tubules, there will be an increase in 
the reabsorption of lithium leading to lithium toxicity. Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is 
often divided into the following three grades: A fine tremor is common in patients taking lithium at therapeutic doses. Therapeutic lithium 
tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the arms, and nonprogressive. The tremor from lithium 
toxicity is coarser and more disabling, may also affect the legs, and occurs with other symptoms of 
toxicity. Other adverse effects include mental confusion, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes 
insipidus, and edema. As lithium is readily dialyzed, lithium overdose or toxicity is treated with hemodialysis. *Note - Serum Na+ levels are significant with respect to lithium toxicity, where as serum 
potassium levels becomes significant in digoxin toxicity. Hypokalemia increases the risk of

questions.question:
Question 13: A 28-year-old woman on lithium therapy now presents with a positive urine pregnancy test. 
Which of the following teratogenic effects can be expected in the fetus?
questions.explanation:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy. 327 
Sold by @itachibot In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which drug, when given to a mother in her third trimester of pregnancy, would result in the 
following finding in her newborn? 322 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Benzodiazepines, when given during the third trimester of pregnancy can lead to floppy baby 
syndrome. Benzodiazepines in pregnancy: • First trimester - cleft palate, GI anomalies • Third trimester - floppy baby syndrome with neonatal hypotonia, as a withdrawal effect. Note: Fetal lithium exposure is also associated with floppy baby syndrome. 328 
Sold by @itachibot Drugs for Parkinson’s Disease
